People don't tell you that after the cute little baby phase comes the overwhelming, tough, and stressful phase. I was a young mom and had very little patience when I had my oldest daughter. She wasn't a bad kid now that I look back at it, she was a normal and curious little girl. I found myself yelling at her all the time. I am not proud of it at all. I remember telling myself to be easier on her and not yell at her, yet I still continued to do so. I have deep regret for how I treated her as a child. I never hit her but I was constantly yelling at her which is just as bad. She would yell back at me and how could I blame her. She was learning from me. I finally got it but I always worry it was too late. I hate to think that I damaged her emotionally but I'm sure I did. She is an amazing, smart and loving  little 8 year old girl now and I am so proud to be her mom. My point is, it's not too late to change. How we treat and raise our kids in their younger years really effect who they are later in life. If we respect them they will learn to respect us. Parenting is very hard but you can do it :-)

I was in a very similar situation before.  I was 19 with twin baby boys and newly married to a marine who got out then decided to do construction and leave me in NC near his family (who didn't help)for months on end with no job,  no license and no friends or family. We moved from overseas while i was 7 mo pregnant. I had preeclampsia and went into seizures,  Almost died.  Had horrible post partum. When the boys were toddler aged i found myself miserable with life.  I yelled at them constantly. I was so mean to them.  We lived above his parents store in a run down loft like thing.  Was dirty, so cold... i know how you're feeling. You're heading down a path where regret and guilt will follow.  I am remarried now and the twins are almost teens.  We have a 6 yr old and a baby girl on the way. We own a home, I am truly happy.  But i have regret. My 6 year old is wonderful.  However i didn't yell at him for the same things i yelled at the twins for.  It makes me feel less than a good mother.  I sucked as a mommy to my twins.  No amount of loving them now will make up for it. Their  behavior, attitudes, choices they make,  I will forever wonder if that's my fault. I guess my point is this.  I know it's hard and impossible right now.  You have to put yourself on hold for your kid. But please try to find help. Find a playdate partner or something.  You need space to breathe. It's hard enough trying to be a good mother with help around. Let your kid get dirty, play with your pots and spoons. Let him play with the clean laundry before you fold it.  Then show him how to help you do it and tell him what a great helper he is! You have to make it ok for you to be unorganized sometimes with him kicking things over and such. That is totally normal.  You have to find something else for him to do.  Have art time with him,  do stuff to keep him occupied. You'll be ok.  :) Hang in there. Just keep telling yourself that you're doing the best you can. That's all any of us do.

You know, I found it helped me to get out of the house.  Especially with that age child.  Now, it's the dead of winter right now but it will soon be spring. I really recommend taking him outside to a park or anywhere (do you have a car or anything?) if you can't drive, then walk.  Oh my gosh, kids do so much better when they get out and run and blow off that energy and steam.  My kids slept better, behaved better, just better all the way around.  Plus, I was able to meet other moms of young kids.  Just like you strike up conversations here, you'll do that with other moms. Socializing isn't work with two moms . . .   they can get on a roll about there kids pretty easily.  :>)There is also something called MOPS.  It's Mothers of Preschoolers.  It's for moms like you.  You go to a meeting and they have child care and you sit with the other women and have a speaker that talks about something that moms like to hear (like organizing, communicating with husband/partner, cleaning, cooking, etc.), food to eat, we always made a craft to take home too.  It is a great way to easily meet other parents near you.  Most people are feeling a little isolated at home that join so they are EAGER to make friends.  One of my best friends is a mom I met in MOPS. Google your area and see where the meetings are.  They are usually at churches but you don't have to belong to that church or be religious to join.I worry a little about your anxiety.  That is something to talk to your doctor about.  They can help you hon.  Medication can be a god send.anyway, sorry it is hard.  I appreciate your honest and hope it gets better for you.  BTW, head start could be a good thing too.  Some super active kids have a bit going on that a professional can spot and begin early intervention with (which is so wonderful for helping a child get on track).  good luck

Well,  I'm glad you know not to leave him outside all by himself.  He needs your near-constant supervision in the house,  unless he is in his crib or playpen,  and he can't be without you outside for even a minute.I think you need a playgroup.  I know you say you're shy,  but if you get together with 3 or 4 other moms on a weekly basis (say,  every Wednesday morning or so) that will help you a lot.  Other moms with babies are SUCH a  blessing,  and such close and dear friends when you all have babies.He's a cutie pie.  It sounds like you are kind of surprised by his activity level,  but it sounds pretty normal to me.  i was never able to sit and write a long post while my babies were that age and mobile.Playgroups aren't something set up by the country or government or whatever,  you set them up yourself with neighbors or moms you meet at a local park or through your library story hour or doctor's office,  or your husband's work friends wives,  etc.
